title: 110_s851
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2007" and introduces the Higher Education Opportunity Credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit allows eligible students to receive tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. The credit amount is based on a percentage of expenses paid, with limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit allows eligible students to receive tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. The credit amount is based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions based on specific income thresholds. The tax credit for eligible students is based on the taxpayer's gross income for the year, excluding certain amounts. There are limitations on the credit amount based on the taxpayer's tax liability and other credits claimed. The credit is only allowed for up to 3 eligible students per year and can be claimed for a maximum of 4 taxable years. Limitations on the education tax credit include: not being able to claim the credit for a student for more than 4 prior years, requiring the student to be at least a half-time student for part of the year, and denying the credit for students convicted of a felony drug offense. The education tax credit cannot be claimed for a student convicted of a felony drug offense before the end of the taxable year. Eligible students must meet specific requirements and carry at least half the normal full-time workload. Qualified tuition and related expenses are defined under this subsection. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes tuition, fees, and 50 percent of book expenses for eligible students at an educational institution. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes tuition, fees, and book expenses up to $250 for eligible students, excluding sports, games, hobbies, nonacademic fees, and expenses unrelated to academic instruction at an eligible educational institution. An educational institution is defined as an institution eligible for participation in a program under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Taxpayers can choose not to apply this section to qualified tuition and related expenses. Special rules include the requirement to identify individuals and adjustments for scholarships. The amount of qualified tuition and related expenses for an individual may be reduced by certain scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and payments for educational expenses that are excludable from gross income under specific laws. Qualified tuition and related expenses paid by a dependent may be treated as paid by another taxpayer if a deduction is allowed for the taxpayer. Prepayments for academic periods starting within the first 3 months following the taxable year are considered paid during that year. In the first 3 months after the taxable year, academic periods are considered to begin in that year. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for deduction elsewhere. Married individuals must file joint returns for this section to apply. Nonresident  aliens must elect to be treated as resident aliens for this section to apply. Inflation adjustments apply to the section's dollar limitation on the credit amount. Inflation adjustments increase dollar amounts under subsection (a) for taxable years after 2008. Dollar amounts are adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. Income limits for taxable years after 2008 are set at $70,000 and $140,000. "Income limits for taxable years after 2008 are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $1,000, it is rounded down. The Secretary may issue regulations for implementing this section, including recapture of the credit." The section discusses the repeal of the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, along with corresponding conforming amendments to other sections of the Code. The text discusses amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to sections 72(t)(7), 221(d), 529, and 530. Amendments involve replacing references to specific sections with new ones. Amendments to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve replacing references to specific sections with new ones, such as section 25A being amended in sections 530, 1400O, 6050S, and 6213(g)(2). The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by replacing the item relating to section 25A with a new one. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit applies to expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for education in academic periods starting after that date.
